But Clarence is that much more charming as we realize he is simply unleashing the superman who has been waiting inside him for just such a chance to battle his way past anything that wants to spill his entrails. Clarence and Alabama are too likable for a viewer to want them any other way; the more they run from impending torture and death and gangster smart-aleckiness as only Tarantino can write such stuff, the more it seems like just a trick to lure various creeps into their clutches. The lowlifes never quite see what hits them--if Clarence and Alabama are good at one thing, it's being underestimated. Sometimes this even compensates for Clarence constantly leaving a trail that Wrongway Feldman could follow.One of the best scenes involves a cadre of gunsels, led by Christopher Walken, getting led to Clarence's father, played Dennis Hopper, thanks to Clarence's carelessness. The gangsters want the father to lead them to the son and his new girl. Walken using scare tactics on Dennis Hopper--I mean, you could flip the roles around and have just as terrific a scene...and heck, it takes a Walken to scare a Hopper. Anyway, once that bit of ugly words and deeds comes to its conclusion, James Gandolfini gets sent off on his own to get the cocaine and bury our brave couple. Full marks to a superb Gandolfini, who corners Alabama/Patricia Arquette while Clarence is off in some washroom reading a book--ack!, no wait, he's off getting munchies. Now, ahem, James Gandolfini versus Patricia Arquette seems more of an easy bet than sorting out odds on Walken versus Hopper. That said, the scene contains a few surprises, and where it looked as if any later scene involving Clarence selling a monster bag of coke to a sleazy movie producer would be minus an Alabama, our wild, plucky heroine with the cocaine shows her hidden side too.Tony Scott would later riff on his own finale to this movie by essentially borrowing it for another fun movie, Enemy Of The State, but both versions demonstrate that the bigger the crowd present for a drug buy (at least in the case of True Romance), the more rewarding for anyone who gets to watch it from a safe vantage point. The kitchen sink is not present for the final stand-off, but everyone else with a gun and an ego shows up. Perhaps Clarence and Alabama's dreams of flying to some tropical paradise with a couple hundred grand have finally led to a situation they can't charm their way out of: conflagration incarnate.This is a cool, slick crime movie starring a loving couple who, though they are doing bad things to get their own slice of the pie, are not doing unspeakably horrendous things for more than their slice, while enjoying some nasty slicing. This separates our lovable anti- heroes from most of the other characters, and gives a fun, bubbly duo to cheer for, while the rats follow the cheese. Swiss cheese.

This film has been my number one for the last 10 years! I can't fault it! It has absolutely everything, from romance, mobsters to even kung fu! I can watch this film again and again! From its superb acting to filmography; it's the type of film I only wish I would work in one day!The character development is amazing and very relatable, being that Clarence is your 'everyday-man'. ALSO not forgetting this amazing soundtrack; it is so unbelievably beautiful and just fits the whole film perfectly! Hands down i'll give this film a 10, for me it is just my favourite, I cant say its the best film I have ever seen but, oh, do I keep coming back!

the greatest movie in the history of film period. Period Period Period How this is a 7.9 or whatever is a sin and a disgrace. This is too high to rate because every scene is perfect, that is the sign of a truly wonderful piece of art. This has it all, and in my opinion is as I said before a perfect film from start to finish. Rarely does this happen.. Gary Oldman is almost to good to put in words, amazing... astounding, insane.. Every scene every word is as if it were taken from real life, as if the story was told as it is. A fragment of someones reality that works on every level.. THe only film I can say is Completely Perfect... I could say not one thing should be changedPERFECT

Tarantino's script for this film is very mature...its best viewer is a viewer who watches a lot of movies.Many of the scenes are striking not only for their plainly-observable actions, but also for the method by which the scenes are played out.IMO, it is difficult to write a movie script that talks about movies, yet Tarantino expertly weaves in and out of characters, drama and violence as though he his stitching his own kickass boxing gloves for a brawl out West.True Romance consists of scenes that stand firmly on their own ground. You could pluck a scene from True Romance and show it as its own clip and the viewer might walk away slightly dazed but with a lucid point of view.For example:-The Dennis Hopper & Christopher Walken scene-When Alabama kills that guy-All of the Drexl scenes-All of the Lee Doniwitz scenesNevertheless, True Romance is packed with interesting characters that offer cohesion - - more so than just by good actors reading good lines. The actors seem to be knowledgeable that they are part of something great, and their performances, spoken words and subtleties reflect that greater knowledge.Not for the timid, True Romance may influence your movie theater candy-stand decision on whether you should purchase the Gummi Bears, or whether to go full throttle and get the all-beef frank.

i didn't see this movie until recently, and it is one of those 90's film that just invokes nostalgia for that time and in many ways captures the essence and style of a period in time. I dont know what it is about quentin taratino but many of the projects he's involved with provoke this response.Even though I know he was unhappy about natural born killers, i love that movie and feel the same way about it, you coould probally say the same for pulp fiction. True Romance is one of the greatest films to come out of the 90s, every scene, every line, every shot! Some movies just do it for you, this is one of those movies for me. If you havent seen this movie watch it with your girlfriend.

reviews.review_title: What's NOT to like about this flick?!?
reviews.content: OK... you have the GREAT dialog of Quentin Tarantino, Christian Slater in the BEST role of his life, Dennis Hopper playing a compassionate man with balls of steel, Gary Oldman being scarily phenomenal, Val Kilmer playing ANOTHER rock star, Brad Pitt being himself, James Gandolfini prepping for the Soprano's, Patricia Arquette playing a sexy Southern gal steered wrong, Chrispher Walken the Sicilian n*gger, Bronson Pinchot finally breaking free of Balkey, Sam Jackson getting his ass-whooped, etc. etc...Doesn't that sound fun???

reviews.review_title: A racist Dennis Hopper, stoned Brad Pitt and a cameo by Tony Soprano... Cool!
reviews.content: Watching True Romance for the second time, I realised that it worked best to think of it as several brilliantly written and acted segments, strung together loosely by able direction (from the "other" Scott) and a "whatever" kind of plot.When I think of this film, the moments that come to mind are Clarence and Alabama eating pie at a dingy little diner, Clarence confronting Gary Oldman's wigga Drexl in his crack den, the classic Sicilian scene between Dennis Hopper and the inimitable Christopher Walken, James Gandolfini interrogating Bama at the motel.Then, I pause and try to remember how the characters got from the diner to Clarence's bed... And what happened directly prior to Gandolfini's scene? And how and when did Bama and Clarence get to L.A., anyway?I can't freakin remember! And this is simply because these are the wind- down moments, the story progression which takes a back seat to the writing and directing style, which are interchangeable at best and, when worse, totally pointless. This films is like Pulp Fiction lite, a collection of interrelated vignettes that ultimately build to something resembling a climax. The only difference is that I could virtually re-enact any and every scene of Pulp Fiction for you at the drop of a hat, because it's ALL vignette, and it's ALL written like these segmented parts of Romance, which is decidedly less memorable because of it.But, I mean, what kind of criticism is that: "It's not as cool as Pulp Fiction." Jesus wasn't as cool as Pulp Fiction.So, 8/10, because the characters are endearing (especially Arquette as Alabama), the dialogue is undoubtedly Tarantino and because, watching it, I always envision what could have been a generic and insignificant film transcending its own genre and setting, all thanks to QT and, I suppose, even a little bit of help for Scott...And also for the Sicilian scene. God, I love that scene!!!

reviews.review_title: If only QT had done it...
reviews.content: Tarantino sold this script in the 80s to attempts to raise funds for the making of Reservoir Dogs. For me, this is a great shame. Tony Scott was handed the duty of trying to turn it into a great film after the success of Reservoir Dogs, but failed. Each scene is just about pieced together in the most standard possible way, and Scott brings absolutely nothing to film of any distinguishable note. The awesome cast, obviously attracted by Tarantino's script (which hard large parts edited by Scott, including a different ending), is undoubtedly a true ensemble of modern greats, and yet Scott does them no favours. He gives the film virtually no direction, and keeps everything simple and safe like many of his other films. The lead characters played by Christian Slater and Patricia Arquette, seem dazed and confused through most of the film, and do nothing to grip the audience. Slater's character, for example, makes a bizarre transformation from loner to drug dealer, without ever really drawing a line between the two.The film keeps itself moving but by no means at a excitable rate as you predict each scene before it starts. It's one saving grace however, is a truly fantastic scene between two Hollywood heavyweights - Walken and Hopper. In Chris Walken's only scene in the film, he dominates and becomes his ruthless Mob boss character. Hopper is superb as a father hiding his son's secret. Apart from this intense scene (you can cut it with a butter knife), the film has no other stand outs, and is quite disappointing and an anti-climax.... if only Quentin Tarantino could of directed it, we could of ended up with a far superior piece of film...I would still recommend it to all film fans, if not only because of the Walken/Hopper scene... if it wasn't for that, there would be no point in seeing it.

If you finish watching True Romance and you didn't enjoy it, you have to be brain dead, but to think the film is perfect you would also have to be brain dead.  Tony Scott's True Romance seems to have the same energy, style, and craft that Tony Scott's previous film had, The Last Boy Scout.  The only difference is that Quentin Tarantino's script had no small part in Tony Scott making a great film.  After watching the film once you are sure to fall head over heels for it.

reviews.review_title: You will have True Love for True Romance
reviews.content: True Romance, I have seen this movie about 50 times, No lie. And I can tell you right now, that every time I have watched it, I liked it even more. One reason why I did not write this review a long time go, when the movie came out is..... well...... The movie came out in 1993. Im 25 now and I'm pretty sure it was not a good movie for a lil dude to watch . But let me tell you, when i got older, I was never so happy to find an older movie that I loved Right off the bat! So that being said, let me give you a lil plot summary to spice up this review a bit. Clarence and Alabama are newlyweds who acquire an unexpected wedding present. Unknown to the blissfully happy couple, ruthless gangsters are on their tail, determined to reclaim their lost property......First I wanna get into the writing. Quentin Tarantino Is a great, great writer, Known for writing movies like, Reservoir Dogs, Pulp Fiction, Natural born Killers, From Dusk Till Dawn , Jackie Brown, Kill Bill vol 1 and 2, Death Proof, Inglourious Basterds and his upcoming film Django Unchained (which he all directed). So Obviously he has skills. but even with all those great movies under his belt. I think that True Romance is the best thing he has wrote..... SO far that is. and thats saying A lot. Just the way the story moves along and keeps you interested is Beautiful!!!!! By the end of the movie you feel like you know these characters and you actually care for them. You don't want anything bad to happen to them or worse die. The Directing, Tony F-ing Scott (Tony Scott) WOW! Known for Directing (just gonna say the ones i like) Top Gun, Crimson Tide, Enemy Of the State, Spy Game, Man On Fire, Domino, Deja Vu, The taking of Pelham 123, and unstoppable. In True Romanced He did an Outstanding job capturing the scenes and angles where you actually feel like your in the room with the characters. You feel there tension, the love, the hate and the innocence. For Example there is a scene with a GANGTER/PIMP (gary Oldman, Believe it or not) and Clarence (Christian Slater), In this scene you feel and see the anger clarence has towards this pimp, but its the way Tony Scott presents these scenes with there theme and mood that get the hairs on your neck to LITERALLY stand up. True Story, It happens to me every time i watch it. And it happens more then once.The Music, First off i wanna say Hans Zimmer is the man and if you have read any of my other reviews you will know that he is one of my favs. Known for (Seriously there is way to many so I'm only saying a few, and that's still gonna be a lot) Inception, Gladiator, The Dark Knight, Batman Begins, The Da Vinci Code, Black Hawk Down, The Last Samurai, The Rock and The Lion King. So in this film the music sounds like we are about to go to an island and drink pina coladas or go lay on the beach in the nice hot sun........ Sorry not happening here. Instead it throws you off a lil and makes you focus on whats going on in the film. thats what i always liked about Hans, he really sets the theme. But he doesn't always have a song playing in the background. Sometimes its just sounds and weird noises (BUT ITS MUSIC) . SO ALLLLLL OF ^THAT^ being said. Do I think you should go see this movie? What do you think? YES DUUUUUHHHH! The cast is SUPERB, You got Christian Slater (The guy who falls in love), Patricia Arquette ( The girl that falls in love with the guy), Dennis Hopper (The Guys Innoncent Father), Val Kilmer ( ELVIS.... Yes Elvis), Gary Oldman (Ganster/Drug Dealer/Pimp), Brad Pitt (Stoner on the couch, yes that is literally his role the whole movie), Christopher Walken (The DON of the MAFIA Family in this film), Samuel L. Jackson (Drug Dealer), Michael Rapaport (Cop), James Gandolfini (Mafia Muscle/Hit-man). I mean the cast ALONE is worth the watch. But then you got Quentin Tarantino Writing it, Tony Scott Directing it, hans Zimmer Composing it. LIKE what could be better? NOTHING! The definition of this movie is "WIN WIN"THIS MOVIE is a 10 out of 10 ALL DAY!

I have never seen a dialogue so pretty and pure as the one between Walken and Hopper in True Romance. Amazing. But the rest of the movie did not disappoint me either.True Romance is a Fast, thrilling movie with a great cast. Every actor shows his best side.  Vote: 10!!!

True Romance is one of those movies that could be easily mistaken for being just another pointless violent action movie.  What separates it is the love story at its core.Penned by master-of-dialog Quentin Tarantino, True Romance is witty, touching, and quite badass.  The movie's plot is character-based, so the situations change around our main characters, played to key by Slater and Arquette.Speaking of actors, this movie has one of the best-assembled ensemble casts I've ever seen, and they all play their characters to the bone.  Christopher Walken is the mobster "antichrist", Oldman is the violent psychopath, Pitt's a stoner, Hopper's a retired cop with just a bit of fire left in his blood. Together, they're both entertaining to watch, and have great chemistry (the Walken/Hopper scene is classic).Overall very funny, violent, and Tarantino, True Romance also succeeds in being a genuinely good love story, that, despite all that blood, is really quite touching.

reviews.review_title: Tarantino's best story. It would be worth it just for seeing the eggplant scene
reviews.content: One of my all-time favorites. Great mix of romantic-criminal movie. Christina Slater and P.Arquette do a good job, but Dennis Hopper is superb in the scene with C. Walken. The eggplant dialogue is in my opinion one of the best movie quotes ever. It also has some really good violence scenes in wich the action look very real (if you like that like i do, it's your movie). Much better than Pulp Fiction

An ensemble cast, some great lines, the whole cast is superb, need to see this movie a few times to catch some of the stuff you miss the first time. My favorite line "Who the f**k is Dick" - just about pd myself with that one. The film starts slowly, and just when you are about to switch off the tape, and hit rewind, lo and behold, it is suddenly "white boy day", and the rollercoast ride begins - great stuff

Dear Arm Chair Critics,The Story is not a bad yarn, I actually enjoyed it,especially Patrica Arquettes performance,..her rather erotic goodbye kiss to her new daddy in law,made me wince with embarrassment,also her gutsy encounter with the henchman in the Motel whilst the boyfriend was out getting Pizza...Wow did that girl have BALLS.I had to mention those 2 scenes,in my opinion that were worth mentioning. out of 10 definitely a good 6!

Bravo to Tony Scott who directed this film. I was really quite impressed with the outcome of this film. It was a Tarantino script which practically guarantees the viewer that what they are about see is full of wonderfully crafted violent sequences, smart storyline and wonderful characters that are wildly entertaining and sometimes dark and mysterious.So, the movie's plot is really quite simple. it centres on a loner guy, Clarence (Christian Slater), who inherits a call-girl, Alabama (Arquette) for one night on his birthday thanks to his boss whom we never meet funny enough. Anyway, Alabama pretends to be interested in kung-fu movies and comic books in order to entice Clarence. She succeeds. Alabama however, after a night of steamy love-making with Clarence, falls for him and admits it along with the admission of her being a call-girl. The flow of events that follows are really quite intriguing and are punctuated with as star-studded cast that is bound to wetten the taste-buds of any movie buff. We have Gary Oldman as Drexy Spivl, a cocaine obsessed WIGGER of a pimp who Clarence kills when he arrives at Drexl's joint to pick up Alabma's possessions. Then we have Val Kilmer as Clarence's sub-conscious alter-ego and despite never actually seeing his face, we are entranced by his words of wisdom to Clarence and we are persuaded into thinking of him as a kind of Elvis like character. Following on, we have Dennis Hopper as Clarence's father, an ex-cop whom is unwillingly and unknowingly entwined into Clarence's mess after Clarence kills Drexl Spivy and Hopper meets an untimely death at the hands of Vincenzo Coccotti (Christopher Walken).Adding amusing turns are Brad Pitt as a stoner room-mate of Clarence's friend Dick and among others, Chris Penn as a hard-hitting but determined cop on the trail of some huge cocaine deals in and around Hollywood. Oh I cant forget Samuel L Jackson's brief turn as Big Don who is on screen for about 30 seconds discussing eating pussy and ass. Hilariously vulgar!Scott uses vivid colours and compelling dialogue to entrance the viewer and the film is given a somewhat light-hearted tone thanks to the xylophonic jingle of Hans Zimmer.Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this film and wasn't deluded beforehand into expecting some sort of masterpiece that should ave swept me of my feet. No, what I expected was a well-scripted, well-acted and skillfully directed film that produced a few laughs and thrills. That's exactly what I got and was entirely satisfied. 9/10. Highly recommendable!
One of the GREATEST movies of all time...but then again pretty much everything Tarantino touches turns into gold lol...Top notch cast as well...Tony Scott's top movie in my opinion

I really thought this was an excellent film. I thought it was good how it was a love story with a twist, but what a love story, they would do anything for each other. A cast of fine actors with the supporting cast including Christopher Walken and Gary Oldman performing as well as Slater and Arquette. It is the scenes which include their characters which really make the film so good, I thought the Drexell scene was very funny. The Tarantino influence is obvious and it would have possibly been even better directed by him. There was less violence than I expected but this was necessary to understand the characters such as the Arquette/Gandolfini scene. This is definitely a film I will watch again and again.

(Minor Spoilers) I have seen this movie twice now and I really do like it. The actors  and plot are great. It is a pretty typical Tarantino flick. A guy kills a pimp and steals his drugs. Therefore the mob goes after him. They have many encounters with the mob along the way and Patricia has an awesome BLOODY fight with a mobster and she kicks his ass. It is just great! They also meet up with an old friend of Clarence's and his roomate turns out to be Brad Pitt. It is pretty hilarious to see Brad Pitt acting like a burned out stoner before he really hit the big time. He is also great in Kalifornia by the way. Anyway the cops catch on and it leads up to a great shootout at the end. If you are into violent action flicks this is great and you will probably like it.

reviews.review_title: The greatest love story ever told on film
reviews.content:
True Romance is one of the all time great films and for me has the greatest love story ever told on film. I've never rooted for a couple in a film more. All characters are wonderful and I believe this was the great James Gandolfini's audition for the role of his life,Tony Soprano, he just didn't know it yet.Hopper & Walken truly magnificent and Slater was never better
I must have watched this film 50 times and I'll watch it 50 more
Magnificent motion picture.

The Christopher Walken Dennis Hopper Scene was a 10 best all time scene. Those two great actors had never appeared in a film together before. They worked together again in 1995's SEARCH and DESTROY but there was no way to recapture the magic of TR's pivotal trailer scene. Maybe someday someone will write a movie that has Hopper,Walken,Oldman,Guy Pierce, Christian Bale,Michael Caine,Gene Hackman,and Tommy Lee Jones. Now that would be a cast. Batman Begins did have four of the above. And fans of the film P.C.U. know that Caine and Hackman appeared in A BRIDGE TOO FAR together, creating the basis for a character's doctoral thesis. But I digress. Quentin Tarantino should get his True Romance/Pulp Fiction groove back and use the above suggested cast.

reviews.review_title: Another Tarantino classic? I don't think so.
reviews.content:
This was such a Stupid film I was Cringing the whole second half.
Man...the only good thing about it I felt was Gary Oldman and that's about it. But he too comes and goes.
Such an Ensemble yet too thin of a Script, the movie's all over the place.
The moments of tension were just ridiculous and Felt comic in a Way, can't say if they were intentional or made in a Serious note.
The part where the Goon's asking Alabama for the Case with Coke in their Honeymoon Suit and Beats her up till he gets what he wants, that's where I seriously felt the Movie is Screwing up and Going downhill big time.
And the climax, the cops show up with a force having no more than 5 people lol, seriously? And they do not even have Bullet vests on. To be short, the thing just feels lazy Writing all the way through. How this movie got rated this high and Gathered such a Fan base is beyond me.
The movie is Basically held together by Random Camios by Phenomenal actors.
It's a mess of a Film....intentionally and unintentionally...
Gosh...

reviews.review_title: Amazing, while Comparable to Pulp Fiction
reviews.content: Pulp Fiction is seen as Tarantino's best movie, but True Romance is overlooked. While it wasn't directed by Tarantino and doesn't go into situations as bizarre as Pulp Fiction, True Romance was one of his first screenplays. Fortunately it was picked up by Tony Scott after being sold. You know how people say things are "high-octane" when the stuff has energy, but they don't want to think of a real way to explain it? Octane is the oxygen in gasoline that makes it burn slower in cars to get more mileage. This movie had the right amount of octane to be fast-paced, but not blow past its human moments. There was plenty of nitrous-oxide on the way to help it be batshit crazy.The first twenty minutes of this movie were insane. We see a ridiculous love story that's believable and very well acted by Christian Slater and Patricia Arquette. We see a shootout with a wigger pimp played by Gary Oldman. And most importantly, we see a huge briefcase of cocaine fall into the couple's possession, forcing them to sell it in Hollywood. The story wastes no time moving right along to the conclusion that is a solid example of convergence.The one thing that threw me off was the score. It wasn't fitting in a lot of scenes. Hanz Zimmer is the man as far as movie scoring goes, but it was awkward in this film. It wasn't crime drama music. It was we're-going-to-the-beach-with-our-xylophones-and-bongos-man kind of music. This got in the way of some deeper character moments that would have been better left without music at all, let alone this music. Halfway through the movie this trend of unfitting music tapers off and doesn't disturb the torture scene, the climax, or a few other key pieces.I loved the hell out of every scene in this movie. It was a prime example of both crime and drama. Character is so often shoved to the side in an act of domestic violence by its abusive owner: action. In True Romance, the two concepts were married and stayed together until their chaotic, but fitting and synchronous passing in the last scene. Should I meet the cast and crew, I'll blow them all over-exaggerated air kisses. Mwah to you. Mwah to you. Mwah to this movie. Entertainment with sympathetic characters has happened before us, let it not be forgotten.

Normally I don't write commentaries on things like this but when prompted to do so for this film I felt compelled to do so. This movie could have won an academy award for some of it's scenes! too bad they were too controversial to ever be considered.... Christopher Walken and Dennis Hopper in the trailer scene.... AMAZING! This movie has a cast second to none and has been seen by so few (at least men) due to it's title :) There is comedy, action, drama and even some romance. Something for everyone in my opinion. Just not for the kids ;) If you have not seen this film do yourself a favor and do so. I bet you will thank me or in the case of the women, want to slap me :) and no you don't have to be a huge Quentin Tarantino fan to appreciate this movie. You just have to like movies! Enjoy
This deserves to be up there with Pulp Fiction. The script, the star turns and the set pieces are all perfectly choreographed. Unmissable.

I'd seen this movie sitting on the shelf a few times and just passed it over.  Then I heard about how violent it was.  So this won the toss up over U-turn. The cast and acting in this movie are amazing. Once again, Tarrantino serves up a no-crap array of characters.  Patricia Arquette is EXCELLENT.  i saw this and thought she'd be my new favorite actress, until i remembered how horrible she was in Stigmata. The story is, a guy meets this hooker, they fall in love.  He goes to confront her pimp and ends up killing him and stealing a huge case of coke. The coke belongs to a very big time dealer who then chases after them and finally catches up to them when they try to sell it.  As a guy with a girlfriend, there's a scene where one of the 'bad guys' goes to retrieve the drugs and finds Arquette alone with them that just angered me.  Not in the sense that i was offended by it, but because you become so infatuated with her character you hate to see something done to her.  He basically beats the hell out of her, fortunately she gets payback though. Once again, the cast is great.  I dont recall seeing more than a few no-namers or people i hadnt seen in other films.  We're once again treated to an excellent performance by Chris Penn. i highly highly recommend this.  dont even bother renting it, just buy it.

Some judge that the values the movie transmit are more conservative than counter-cultural or alternative,and that this doesn't prevent it from being a typical Hollywood movie.I think on the contrary that True Romance is quintessentially a Hollywood movie because the values it tries to transmit (the supreme value of the individual against all forms of authority(the police and crime,and on a lighter level,family and traditional moral),life seen as a roller-coaster...)go directly against the traditional American ones.It only serves Hollywood's almost subversive aims to use the pattern of the American Dream,to couple it with the notion of the Hero,and to lend it a woman's voice.

reviews.review_title: An incredible movie filled with top notch cameos of today's hottest actors.
reviews.content: True Romance is my favorite movie of all time.  The story is compelling. The acting is exquisite.  The dialogue is what takes it to another level. The movie is funny in a weird way because of the dialogue.  Gary Oldman should have been nominated for best supporting actor if his role had been a little bit bigger.  Then again, you could say that about Christopher Walken's performance also.  The scene between Walken and Dennis Hopper was absolutely awesome!  Gary Oldman amazes me in every role he portrays.  An English actor that is able to "nail" that "wannabe" accent that Drexl has is just incredible.  It is a very violent movie but it was violent for the sake of being violent.  It was necessary to understand the charachters and their definition of "True Romance".  James Gandolfini shows his brilliance in portraying a mobster strongman which no doubt lead to his casting in The Sopranos.  Tom Sizemore and Chris Penn add interesting dialogue that I particularly found funny.  Even Bronson Pinchot had a good part in this flick.  Saul Rubinek was excellent in portraying fat cat movie producer Lee Donowitz. The Bottom line:  Great short performances out of Oldman, Walken, Hopper, Rubinek,Gandolfini and solid short performances out of Michael Rappaport, Tom Sizemore, Chris Penn,Bronson Pinchot, Val Kilmer and Brad Pitt.  Christian Slater and Patricia Arquette provide their best performances as the two main charachters who define "True Romance" a little differently than the rest of us.  I think the title of the movie threw off mainstream America and mislead them to believe it was a "romance" in the traditional sense.

OK, folks was surfing through the movie channels and True Romance was on, and of course I stopped on it and watched the whole movie again for the 100th time. So it prompt me to come look up info about it AGAIN, and I realize nobody has posted here for years, but I just had to add something.If you read the other comments, you will realize that this is an action packed, star studded movie that snuck under the block buster radar back in 1993. I think the title turns most people off, and I remember a critic saying that back then.But that is my point. If you follow this movie closely, and you know how Quentin loves his dialog, you will realize that this is a very very romantic movie. What Clarence does for his love, is close to what spiderman does in his favorite comic book he talks about. Clarence is just a mild mannered, boring nobody, he's not a gangster or tough guy.. it's just what he is willing to do for his soulmate and to guarantee a happy ever after.OK, enough.. nobody will probably read this.. but I just had to throw my 2 cents in about my most favorite movie of all time. Hands Down.

reviews.review_title: Plain and simple a marvellous movie!
reviews.content: This is just a fantastic movie. It's constantly amusing, and combines beautiful, compact violence with an incredible love story, which engages the viewer to the max. True Romance evolves quickly thoroughly the whole movie. In a matter of minutes, Clarence Worley and Alabama are married. The turning points are made with excellent precision. The music, the cast, and the atmosphere that True Romance delivers, is just a breakthrough for any modern love story committed to the screen today. Patricia Arquette, Christian Slater, Christopher Walken, James Gandolfini and Dennis Hopper are all highly worth seeing.Recommended to anyone with a taste for a wicked, wild, entertaining love story. 8/10

reviews.review_title: Best film ever! Best scene ever - what more is there to say...
reviews.content: What a cracking film this is. All my favourite actors in one film (Oldman, Walken, Arquette, Hopper). I'm not a big Christian Slater fan but he portrays the Clarence character so well. Clarence has so many unexpected sides to his character, comic book store manager for years, then, for love of Alabama kills two men in cold blood and a-whole-nother character appears. Oldman is the business as the psychotic wannabe dread ("it ain't white boy day is it Marty?"). Dennis Hopper excels as the ex-alcoholic father of Clarence (Christian Slater) especially in the best scene the film (the eggplant scene). Best scene in a film ever - what a work of genius both in acting, screenplay and writing. "I haven't killed anyone since 1984".See it, see it again and love it. Tarantino - you are officially the man.

reviews.review_title: Best start to a movie I have ever seen
reviews.content: True Romance is a film that has been rated very highly and rightly so, although I found that when Clarence and Alabama hit the road heading towards LA the film dies a little. Why? I guess because the first 30 minutes was the best start to a movie I have ever encountered and so once there was a change in pace the movie lost interest a little. If I were the director no way I'd kill off such a great character in Drexl so soon.The movie did have a strong ending though when everyone was gathered at the hotel room for the exchange of money for drugs where a final shootout takes place.I enjoyed Val Kilmer who played the mentor just before Clarence was about to make a decision - Killin's the hard part, getting away with it, that's easy. You think a cop gives a f**k about a pimp? Listen. Every pimp in the world gets shot. Two in the back of the f**kin head. Cops'd throw a party, man As long as your not at the scene with a smokin gun in your hand you'll get away with it This movie had so many well known actors who all played their part from Christopher Walken, Dennis Hopper and a younger James Gandolfini. Even Brad Pitt put in a great performance as Floyd who sat around all day smokin drugs.The only weakness I found in this movie was straight after Christopher Walken kills Dennis Hopper which was a scene that was brilliantly written.True Romance was a well written and acted out movie!!!

Before I watched True Romance I knew I would like it.  And as it turned out I liked every minute of it.  The main reason I knew this would be a good movie is because of the director, Tony Scott.  Tony Scott also directed "The Last Boy Scout" which was an awesome movie and one of my all time favorites. But each line in the movie has the Quentin Tarantino trademark on it as Quentin Tarantino did write this movie.  I find this film similar to "Reservoir Dogs" because at the end of the movie at the climax you have everyone in the same room pointing guns at each other.  The cast in "True Romance" is great from Christian Slater, Patricia Arquette, Dennis Hopper, and Christopher Walken.  I especially like Gary Oldman's character as he plays as a pimp.  And you have Val Kilmer playing as Slater's imanginary friend as Elvis.  A great movie.  9 out 10.

reviews.review_title: WOW - what a film, what a cast!
reviews.content: Undoubtedly Tarantino's best, although that sells the film short. This is *not* a Tarantino film - it's a film *written* by Tarantino. That's the main difference, and as I've always thought that his main talent is for writing, rather than direction (and definitely not acting!) that's a plus for a start. What can i say about this film though? It's superbly put together, the characters are so real that they're almost tangible and the film just flows effortlessly from one scene to another. If you still have any doubts about seeing it, just check out that cast list one more time...Dave

reviews.review_title: Open your eyes! Open your F@#KING EYES!
reviews.content: This movie is the best movie of all time. It's written by Quintin Tarantino, so the dialog and story is superb! Tony Scott is the director. Enough said. NOTE: This review is in reference to the Unrated Director's Cut, and it may refer to some scenes not featured in the original release.True Romance has for a long time been considered the middle-piece in a loose trilogy by filmmaker Quentin Tarantino, wedged in between the now-classic Reservoir Dogs (1992) and the always timeless Pulp Fiction (1994). However, I am urged to disagree with public opinion -- as is usual -- and shed some light on why True Romance is not a Tarantino film. Firstly, it is directed by Tony Scott -- a man who's had his moments, but should really leave movie-making to Ridley -- and, therefore, has a very shallow, action-based tone (despite it's desperate attempt to be categorized as independent). This is made extremely evident in some utterly ludicrous "adrenaline-rush" scenes (e.g. the roller-coaster segment) and in the inscrutably dull performance of Michael Rapaport (who plays a poor -- both financially and literally -- actor somehow capable of purchasing rare, out-of-print film posters, framing them, and hanging them on his wall). But I must confess that what irritated me most about True Romance was the ending. For those of you who aren't as well-informed about Quentin and this screenplay, the original ending (SPOILERS AHEAD) involved Clarence being killed in the Mexican stand-off and Alabama becoming a call-girl once again (eventually teaming up with Mr. White from Reservoir Dogs). Tony attempted to justify his compromise -- which is basically having Clarence and Alabama live happily ever after, despite the fact that stole a suitcase full of cocaine and pumped more shotgun shells in their opponents than any other two lovers I've seen on the silver screen -- by saying that (and I quote) "I loved the two main characters so much that I wanted them to get away with it." Although I may not speak on behalf of the reader or any other viewer, I didn't care at all for Clarence or Alabama. Perhaps if their roles had been given to more experienced and "loveable" actors, this ending would have worked. Okay, I will give this to fans of the film: Patricia Arquette isn't bad, but I couldn't stop thinking that Christian Slater looked like the devil. This said, True Romance does have some good aspects: the soundtrack was unique and worked well with the mood, Quentin cleverly incorporated Elvis' ghost into the screenplay, and supporting actors James Gandolfini and Chris Walken are great. The best thing about this movie, though -- and the only thing that keeps me from giving it a lower grade -- is Brad Pitt. His performance is, for lack of a better word, hysterical! And I found it very interesting that even though all he does throughout the film is lie on a couch and get high, he ends up causing half of the deaths in the movie -- and no one even knows it. Also, I feel compelled to mention the recently released 2-disc DVD set, which features Quentin's only audio commentary ever recorded, and a montage of the alternate ending. In conclusion, Tony Scott's interpretation of True Romance might have worked if Pulp Fiction or Reservoir Dogs had never been made, but with shoes that big to fill, it can't help but become a failure.Grade: C-

Written by Tarantino, directed by Scott, composed by Zimmer. This film really is a piece of art and contains nearly every genre in the film industry created to keep viewers at the edge of their seats, as well as to make them feel complete. One of Tarantino's finest scripts, which includes one of his greatest scenes.This film goes from Detroit, to Los Angeles, from Americans, to Sicilians, from love, to crime. True Romance portrays a great storyline, excellent characters, and an amazing soundtrack which can cure any feeling of sadness.Gary Oldman, Christian Slater, Patricia Arquette, and Christopher Walken, without a doubt give their best acting performance in each scene we were blessed to see them in, making each aspect of this film more beautiful, and enjoyable with a satisfactory climax.Despite its 7.9 rating, True Romance is arguably one of the greatest feel-good, and suspenseful movies of its generation, perhaps of all time.

reviews.review_title: Tarantino's best script, one of the best casts ever
reviews.content: Go to the main details page for this film. Then look at the cast. Have you ever seen a better group of actors in one place? I know Christian Slater doesn't have a rep as a great actor, but in this film he is. He stands out above everyone else, and that is high praise indeed when you're comparing him to the likes of Christopher Walken and Dennis Hopper. Actually, speaking of Hopper and Walken, they share one scene together, and it is one of the best I have ever scene. I say this with no exaggeration. It's impossible to look away from. The film is worth watching just for this scene.Christian Slater's character is cool. He works in a comic-book store, has a fixation with Elvis Presley, and on his birthday every year he goes to the cinema alone to watch a Martial Arts Triple Bill. Not exactly a standard definition of cool. But he is. He's the sort of character you'd like to be. I can't work out why though, but he's great.I'm not sure what else I can say about this film. I try to be a harsh marker of films, so I only give films that I think are literally perfect 10/10. Which means that only Shawshank Redemption, the Usual Suspects and Return of the King are rated as a 10 by me. But honestly, this film is as good as any of them*. You have to see this movie.*Except for the Shawshank Redemption. That film deserves about 17/10. Unfortunately that might make the universe implode through some paradox or other.

reviews.review_title: A fantastic action romp and a modern day romeo and Juliet
reviews.content: TRUE ROMANCE:Director: Tony Scott Cast: Christian Slater, Patricia Arquette, Dennis Hopper, Christopher Walken, Val Kilmer, Gary Oldman, Samuel L. Jackson, Brad Pitt Genre: Action, Thriller Certificate: 18 Released: 1993This criminally under-appreciated cult classic is a true masterpiece that deserves to be watched by everyone! From the ridiculously strong casting to the excellent script (written by none other than Quentin Tarintino), almost everything about this movie is stylish, cool and near perfection.As I fore mentioned above, the cast is full of some of the best actors in the business. Christian Slater is in top form as Clarence, a loser working in a comic store who comes across the opportunity of a life time when he and his newlywed wife, Alabama (Patricia Arquette) come across a suitcase of uncut cocaine. They begin their road trip, setting off to sell the lot to a rich client and living off it for the rest of their lives.All is not as easy at is seems, though. Upon their travel they get tracked down by a gang of Sicilian mobsters (led by Christopher Walken) who were the original owners of the cocaine. What follows is a high octane, super stylish chase full of moments of laughter, breathlessness and shock, including one of the most infamous speeches in cinematic history delivered by Dennis "your grandmother f****d a n*****" Hopper. What should also be noted is the quality of directing. The action comes thick and fast with numerous gunfights breaking up the story including the breathtaking finalé proving an obvious highlight and also the shocking scene where Alabama gets beaten to within an inch of her life by one of the Sicilians mobsters. Moments like this are so brilliantly choreographed that it brings out the deepest of emotions from you.All in all this is a movie that simply must be seen as soon as possible. Please don't deny yourself of the experience of this balls out action flick as it is a modern classic and you'll be hard matched to find anything better for a Friday night in.Rating: *****

reviews.review_title: This movie is in my top 10 favorites
reviews.content: Tony Scott did an great job directing this fine film, But all credit must go to Quentin Tarantino he wrote one heck of a script. I know this was one of Tarantino's first scripts, but it could be one of his best. I can understand that at the time Tarantino didn't have enough to budget or get this film off the ground. He did a good move in giving the script to Scott. Scott knows what to do when it comes to movies and i know he let Tarantino make the movie almost like a partner. All of the characters were well thought up and deep. Walken has a great role as does Hopper. Drexel could be one of the best villains of all time. This is one of the 3 movies that all tie in to each other in Quentin's mind. This, Resevoir Dogs, and Pulp Fiction are all connected. With Vincent and Vic being brothers and Mr. White and Alabama being lovers/partners in crime this shows yet another way Quentin is one hell of a script writer. I know the ending is not as Quentin dreamed up, but there is a good viewing of his ending in the Directors cut of this movie. The movie has everything you want. Thrills, Kills, and blood Spills. The movie is also a love story in a true Quentin T. fashion. This movie is probably my favorite movie of all time. its a 10 of 10.

reviews.review_title: A Sign of Things to Come
reviews.content: I've been a fan of Quentin Tarantino since I saw Pulp Fiction almost ten years ago. Not long after that, I rented Reservoir Dogs and also True Romance, and fell in love with them both. I bought Reservoir Dogs on video, but for some reason never purchased True Romance, until recently when I picked up the Special Edition DVD. Time has passed, obviously. I still like Tarantino, and I count Jackie Brown as one of my top ten favorite movies of all time. But True Romance, it seems, hasnt really aged well. Thats not to say that it is, by any means, a bad movie. It's not. What it means is that, looking back on it now, you can see future Tarantino-ism's, before they really matured. Theres the love-story at it's center, not unlike Natural Born Killers (and even to an extent Jackie Brown). The stoner who sits on the couch all day smoking. The Mexican Stand-off. I could go on, but I think you see my point. True Romance was the first screenplay that he wrote, and it makes sense that some of what he wrote would find its way into his other movies. I'm not faulting the movie for that. What I am saying, though, is that if you've seen all of his other movies, then you have seen this.

Like most of you guys I have seen all Tarantino's movies but I have always liked this one the most - to me, as a writer, creating the story or screenplay makes you the author of a movie. Tarantino wrote the movie And Tony Scott was the director. For this kind of writing, directors you can hire.The screenplay is the most important creative process. And Scott changed True Romance to give the movie a happy ending. That was to avoid depressing the US test audience (no doubt in LA). But these days movies make their money worldwide as downloads, so why not test a movie with an international audience? They may well have gone with the original Tarantino ending (which I will not reveal here. Don't want to spoil the lucky first time viewer).True Romance is one of the greatest movies of all time - and one I watch every year. Along with Grosse Pointe Blank, John Wayne's True Grit, the Danish version of Girl With a Dragon Tattoo, The Girl Who Played with Fire and It's a Mad Mad Mad Mad World.Do these movies have something in common? Yes - the story sells the movie. And it rolls along like a barrel down a hill -- you can't help watch where it's going. That is something the writers of the James Bond movies, including Skyfall (boring) should take on board.Ian Flemming took the 'James Bond' name from a book on his shelf. The book, by James Bond is "Birds of The West Indies". That probably had a better story line than Skyfall.Peter

Truly a wonderful movie and probably Christian Slater's best performance. Some may argue with me on this one (that would be your Pulp Fiction die hard fans), but I also believe that it is Quentin Tarantino's best script ever. A deranged love story surrounded by impossible odds. Using street smarts, sometimes, our hero "Clarence Worley" played by Christian Slater, mostly trips and falls out of the way of bad situations. You can see the train wreck coming as the calamity of errors start brewing from the very beginning to it's climatic end. The cameo roles play by Dennis Hopper and Christopher Walken are too good to be missed. I have watched this movie a few times looking for the holes and haven't been able to find even one.

The Ultimate Hollywood FairytaleA script that was (party) written by Quentin Tarantino seems to be impossible to get on film. Nevertheless, Tony Scott took a shot and delivers the fairytale about "the movies". After some modifications in the storyline (which was originally connected to Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs), Scott and co. produced a true classic.Leading character Clarence Worley (Slater) guides you during a wild ride, which contains literally sex, drugs and rock and roll. Basically, the story is about Clarence who meets Alabama (Arquette), a callgirl, falls in love with her and attempts to start a new life with her. However, there are some complications concerning her pimp, Drexl (Oldman). Clarence and Alabama end up stealing cocaine from Alabama's former pimp. The newlyweds decide to sell the drugs in Hollywood, finding themselves chased by the former owners of the "half a mill" worth of drugs. True Romance is a film that should be regarded as the guide through Hollywood. The incredible strong cast (with appearances of, amongst others, Samuel L. Jackson, Brad Pitt, Christopher Walken, James Gandolfini and Dennis Hopper) delivers the most comic, over exaggerated, varying and creative characters imaginable. Literally every part of this movie is overdone; from the Elvis impression by Kilmer, to the stereotype director Donowitz (Rubinek). Why then, do I rate this movie with 8 points out of the 10 possible? Simply because in this movie the interaction between the actors in every scene is just fantastic, which truly is the engine of the picture. Above that, the dialogues are brilliant, and you will find yourself laughing out loud on more than 1 occasion. Most of the times it is not a good sign when you are laughing out loud during serious dialogues in an action-filled motion picture. This is not the case for True Romance. Scott displays the action fairytale in which everything is possible. The choice of exaggerating every character and scene turns out to be the magic touch that turns this movie in to a classic. Although the entire movie keeps you on the edge of your seat, the scene where Walken, playing a mobster, visits Clarence's father, Hopper, is the very best part of this picture. During this scene, which contains of more than 10 minutes of dialogue, you are blown away by the actors' performance, their lines, character and appearance. In this scene, Gandolfini also displays his talent of playing a fearless gangster. True Romance provides an adrenaline rush, which does not stop until the very end. Referring to Gandolfini's character, watching this movie truly feels like tasting the snow at the end of the rainbow. Hollywood's rainbow, that is.

Original director Quentin Tarrantino wrote this movie, but didn't direct it, Tony Scott did. True Romance is about a comic book store clerk named Clarence (played by Christian Slater) who falls in love with a call girl named Alabama (played by Patricia Arquette) after a one night fling. The movie centers around these two characters, and a suitcase full of cocaine Clarence finds after killing Alabama's pimp Drexl (played by Gary Oldman) in his sleazy whore house. After realizing they have a suitcase full of cocaine, this takes them down a journey that involves the mafia, police officials, and the movie industry. I would tell you more, but you should go see it yourself. I gave this 6 stars because I felt the romance part of the movie took away a lot of the excitement (or it could of been Tony Scott's directing ability that did it). I also didn't like the ending because I thought it built you up for something good, then evaporated into nothing. But, there are a couple of good scenes in the movie you will enjoy such as the Sicilian scene between Christopher Walken & Dennis Hopper, and the hotel room scene between James Gandolfini & Patricia Arquette. All in all a fairly entertaining flick.

Tarantino did well in writing this film.  I have mixed feelings about his acting, writing, and directing talents - in other words, I hate Natural Born Killers and From Dusk Till Dawn, and love Reservoir Dogs and Pulp Fiction. True Romance is added to the love list.  The great cast and respectable plot, combined with Tarantino's wit, make True Romance a quality film.  I give it an 8 out of 10. The best scene is with Dennis Hopper being interrogated by Christopher Walken and his thugs.

reviews.review_title: Such an amazing movie you'll love it forever!
reviews.content: This is my favourite movie, I've not seen it until tonight for 5 years, and I think it's a film you MUST watch every 5 years. It's a great feel good movie with some grunt behind it. Alabama is very beautiful, and with cleavage to fall in love with, Christian Slater is "so cool" you wanna be him. Great cinematography, lovely soundtrack, unpretentious. Just worth the experience! Annoyingly I must now have 10 lines to make this a "proper" review - because I've said all I want to say, but please watch it, it's a 1990's movie that stands the test of time, and very few movies do that. It's fun to spot the famous actors in their hey day. It's only 3 quid and a must for every movie collection.

Quentin Tarantino's writing is what the movie's were made for. Living characters hiding in cliched but rich characters The criticism it received for it's emphasis on violence, and extrapolation of characters is most likely the same criticism Spielberg received when he took aliens and comic-book heroes like Indiana Jones, and revered them into movie theaters.
Quentin took the people that read the dime magazine romance novels, underground comics that treat love like a child's plaything, mobsters that are aware of their own violence, and placed them in the world as it can horribly turn out to be.I'm a big romantic comedy fan, and could empathize with how many details are peppered onto Patricia Arquette's character as the woman of someone's dreams. She might not be perfect, but she reminds that the woman you fall in love with aren't perfect, and that's why you love them.
The first few scenes between the two of them evolve so naturally and at the same time with that dime-magazine exaggeration that it becomes compelling to love them and judge them. Especially when you can distance yourself from them, call them comic-geeks and white trash. Where the writing gets you is that you still love these two, because they're as afraid of waht they're into as any could ever be.The violence is effective. Your heart is broken when you realize how much your heart could possibly bleed for years knowing that while your lady was dying for you in a hotel room, you were out buying burgers and talking about Elvis. And dying because she thought you to be the woman you always wanted to be for somebody but you know you're not. The love of a good woman, who ain't perfect but lives in a reality that makes you the strongest man alive is a truly romantic way to live forever. It's the biggest most deliciious slice of America's culture that anybody could want. It's America, living fast, making fresh new love in a phone booth in the desert, while the biggest truck in the world rolls past. 10/10

reviews.review_title: Good golly, I dig me some Alabama, Clarence, and Floyd!
reviews.content: Light it up.  This film set me on fire. Every performance is magnificent. Quentin knows how to write dialogue like no one alive. These characters live in my dreams. Tony Scott's unique direction worked perfectly for this film (as it does for most of his projects) and this brilliant cast carried out his vision superbly. Thank you god for this movie.  Good old fashioned gunfights and sex.

reviews.content: This film has everything.... and i mean everything. Great actors, great script..... it'll make you laugh and it'll make you cry. It is pure genius. Let's name some of the actors in this film! Christian Slater, Patricia Arquette, Gary Oldman, Dennis Hopper, Val Kilmer, Christopher Walken, Brad Pitt, Samuel L. Jackson..... blah blah blah the list goes on. Now don't get me wrong. A lot of these well known names only have a few minutes on screen but trust me when i say that these few minutes are .... well .... genius. My personal favorite is a scene with Walken and Hopper (i don't want to ruin it, not that i could).... but it is what film was made for. This film has a number of rememberable quotes (and if you can't remember them, you will be learning them to tell your friends)..... honestly, you will. The "theme music" for this movie is also perfect. You are guarantied to recognise it. Hans Zimmer!!!! I friend introduced me to this film and if i have introduced it to you, I hope but secretly know you will introduce it to others. It's simply ..... genius!!!

Tarantino was both erroneous and entirely unfair concerning the Sicilian people. Clifford Worley's remarks are as racist as white supremacist Arthur Kemp when he asserts that Sicilians are of a mixed race.  Worley is racist remarks use false historical evidence claiming this just for the sake of race baiting that the Moors are responsible for the injection of sub-Saharan African blood into Sicily. First fact is, the Moors were not black. They were Hamito-Semitic peoples, meaning that they began as Semites from the Near East and then absorbed physically similar Hamites, or Berbers, during their conquest of North Africa, prior to entering Europe. Moors who colonized most of the Iberian peninsula for 800 years are estimated to have left a mere 3.8% genetic imprint on modern Iberians. Hence, those Muslims who held Sicily for a comparatively shorter period of just 250 years and, in their thwarted efforts to take mainland Italy, conquered various Southern Italian cities for periods of less than 100 years, had an even lesser genetic impact on Italian populations.  Secondly the "Norman" King Roger II, the founder of the kingdom of Sicily during the first half of the twelfth century liberated the island from the Islamic yoke. His kingdom was mixed east-west culture and the development of its royal government the most advanced in twelfth-century Europe.   After Roger Sicily was the home to a large Jewish population, became Spanish Colony, and held under the Viceroys of Spain from the late 13th century to the early 18th century making the population more of a Judeo/Greco/España blended ethnicity.  Moreover, the unfortunate blacks that were brought enslaved into Europe by imperialists at the start of the Atlantic slave trade were  absorbed into their host populations, often by way of royal houses. It was Britain, France, Holland and Germany who were then the dominant colonial powers and slave traders.     Therefore, this leads back to Tarantino's statement which can now only be construed to be there for its shock value only; it is total untrue, and never be taken as fact. Unfortunately there are too many white racists out there who take lines from movies as Gospel truth to support and fuel the fires of their own prejudices. For certain, there will be more battles ahead dispelling the myths concerning Sicilian people.Bibliography:For further information look up The Races of Europe, Chapter XII, Section 7, Italy, and http://www.geocities.com/racial_myths/italians.html

The interactions between Walken and Hopper, Slater and Oldman, and Arquette and Gandolfini are all fun to watch. reviews.review_title: This is really Tarantino's best and I loved his other movies
reviews.content: This movie introduces many of today's powerhouse actors and the cast alone is so full of future and current (at the time) stars that it almost can't help but be great. All I will say about the characters is this: watch for Brad Pitt's character, he only has a few minutes, but you won't be disappointed. Also, watch for the scene between Christopher Walken and Dennis Hopper. It may be the best scene in a film that I can remember.The thing that makes it it hard for True Romance to gain the acceptance of other Tarantino's films is that it really is a romance story and most of Tarantino's fans (I assume) are male and are probably not interested and or threatened by watching a "love story". However this is romance Tarantino style with violence and blood galore injected with appropriately timed humor. But like all good movie dramas an attachment to the characters is vital to the emotional impact of the movie and it is the love story in this that makes every gun fight, torture, or death that much more interesting, meaningful, and powerful.If you like other Tarantino movies see this one, you will definitely like it. It is the least known of his movies, his first, and arguably his best

True Romance is an excellent Tony Scott film, although may believe that if Quentin Tarentino (Pulp Fiction) directed it, it could of been even better. True Romance is without doubt one of my favourite films of all time, it has all the assets an action fan would love, guns, drugs and sex. What makes it even better is its impressive cast including Christian Slater, Brad Pitt and Gary Oldman who all greatly compliment this film and represent its brilliance. True Romance is a must watch for all action and Tarentino fans. The choice of letting Tony Scott direct it paid off as this a truly great film to watch.10/10!

When it was said that True Romance was a "Bonnie and Clyde for the 90's", the statement was both true enough to be accurate and false enough to chase off those who may have really enjoyed this movie. What True Romance truly is is an old-fashioned romance put through the pop-culture blender that is the mind of Quentin Tarantino, then interpreted by the ever-imaginative Tony Scott. The actors are entirely comfortable in their roles and mesh together so well that it is hard to believe that many of them were only on set for a day or two. A word of warning: THIS MOVIE IS NOT FOR EVERYONE! Foul language and over-the-top violence abound, but it is all done in good fun. If these elements are not enough to deter you from seeing a movie, do not deprive yourself of such a bona-fied classic entertainment. Bronston Pinchot is genius, Brad Pitt makes his part so much bigger than it really is, and Val Kilmer becomes the greatest actor to ever play Elvis without ever being clearly seen on camera. In short (though this review is anything but), great acting and clear directing took a great script with amazing action and hilarious dialogue and turned it into a classic film.

The atmosphere in this movie is splitted. At the beginning in Detroit, things start pretty calm and pictures and scenery create a compelling atmosphere. Later in the plot in LA things start to happen pretty fast bit by bit and the scenes appear scrappy. only when it comes to the showdown, the movie gains back its good created atmosphere.short appearance but very good acting by Christopher Walken. also James Gandolfini and Brad Pitt make short but good performances. Dialogues seems realistic and convincing to me. The end is a little bit constrained happy for my taste and the music gives the romance of the movie a harmonic but at the same time surreal touch, but i find it incongruous.All in all the movie provides a solid story with some palatable surprises but also some lacks in the well established atmosphere from the beginning. Not good enough to be in the list of my favourite movies or to play in the league of cultmovies but definitely worth a good movie evening.

And that is a remarkable achievement for an action movie.

reviews.review_title: True Romance Baby!!! I loved it Inside Out

So to start with the movie would not have been what it is if it wasn't for the script, the witty dialogue and the dark humor, which was expected from Tarantino So that was not the highlight of the filmFor me the USP of this film, the thing that this film had which normally most films don't have were the brilliant acting performances by each and every actor This film had greats like Brad Pitt, Christopher Walken, Sameul Jackson, Dennis Hopper in character roles!!! Every scene in the film is memorable and has been done with perfection and style... In the lead both Christian Slater and Patricia Arquette were superbThe movie's pace is fast it won't let you take your eyes of it even for a second So if you haven't seen it you don't want to keep yourself away from it... or you will regretI highly recommend this filmP.S. Having watched True Romance, I have now seen every film that Quentin Tarantino has had a major involvement in (i.e the films he wrote and directed, not the ones he presented). It's fair to say that none of them have disappointed me - except Jackie Brown, but I'll moan about that if and when I review it- and True Romance is absolutely no exception!I loved this film, fair and square. But what's so intriguing about it is that it's unlike any of Tarantino's other films...maybe that's because he didn't direct, he only wrote it, and it is slightly lovy dovy - not something I would expect from Quentin! Most of the soundtrack is songs I would never really expect to hear in one of Q.T's flicks (espically the song that's played almost every time someone has an intimate conversation) and a lot of the cast I just would never expect to see in association with him. That may sound a little negative but come on, ask yourself, before you heard of this film, did you really expect to see Gary Oldman in a Tarantino movie...I don't think so! Having said this though, when you listen to some of the dialogue, you can instantly tell it's Q.T's words. I don't really know how to explain it but, you'll know what I mean. Oh and Samuel L. Jackson makes a short appearance too!One of the things that attracted me to this movie was the cast. Gary Oldman (one of my fav's), Brad Pitt, Val Kilmer, Christopher Walken and Dennis Hopper. I'll be honest, I have never seen a Christian Slater movie (other than Robin Hood, but I don't count that as a Slater movie) and I wasn't really all that fussed about seeing him, but I tell you, he just really sits right with Tarantino's screenplay. Of course, I don't really think he was the only actor that could have cast has "Clarence", but he shone none the less. Once more, I felt that he really made a proper connection with Patricia Arquette, or rather "Alabama" - the love interest. Christian and Patricia are the stars of the film and are in pretty much every scene, but all of the other big names get a maximum of 2 scenes - though I think Dennis Hopper had 3. This may come has a bit of a downer to those of you who are looking to see your favourite actor, but don't be disappointed - remember, Anthony Hopkins stole Silence of the Lambs and he was only in it for 15 minutes! Gary Oldman's performance was utterly staggering and slightly frightening; not only was he in a film I didn't him to be in, but he was also playing a role I could never have imagined him as. He plays...wait for it...a pimp who thinks he's black! Who'd of thought Commissioner Gordon could pull that off? The one scene that Christopher Walken is in, and I mean ONE, is one of my favourite parts of the film. Chris just reels you in when he says "I'm the Anti-Christ" in his very thick accent! Now, I really enjoy Val Kilmer's films (don't ever mention Batman Forever to me though, that film just makes me weep) and I was looking forward to him playing another one of these amazing cameos, but the credits rolled and I just couldn't for the life of me remember seeing him and I'm sure that those of you who watch this film, and don't watch Val on a loop, will feel the same way. I looked at his name in the credits and it says he plays a character called "Mentor" and I had no I idea who the hell he was. But, then it hit me, there are two scenes in the film where Clarence (Slater) is MENTORED by his hero, Elvis Presley, and when looked back at those scenes I thought that Elvis did sound quite a bit like Val's character in Tombstone. So now you know...and knowing is half the battle! Though his face is blurred, so you can't see his questioning face.The soundtrack is simple to judge, all of the songs that feature are stuck in my brain and...I like it!People who will like this: Tarantino fans, Oldman fans, Walken fans, Slater fans, Rom-Com fans, Gangster fansPeople who won't like this: Those who fancy Val Kilmer, those who didn't like Platoon due to it's over-repeated main theme

reviews.review_title: Quentin Tarantino's clever story and great dialogue make this movie a great choice
reviews.content: I rented this movie, after I decided to follow the career of one Quentin Tarantino.  I found the screenplay to be witty, and the story, both paced well, and funny.  The all star cast including Christian Slater, Patricia Arquette, Gary Oldman, Val Kilmer, and Dennis Hopper, under the direction of Tony Scott make this an all-around great film.I encourage fans of Quentin Tarantino to rent this script written very early in his career, and I encourage everyone else to rent it, when their in the mood for a great movie.

It's entertaining, fun, and rewatchable. Although I don't think it's as 'good' or as 'funny' as films like Pulp Fiction and Fight Club, I still seem to wind up watching this film more. Like those films, it has a mixture of light fun and wit, and much darker and harder to watch scenes. Almost all of the 'big name extra' type characters are excellent, especially Pitt, Hopper and Walken, it's just a pity that individually none of them had much screen time. It's not meant to be believable, so don't slam it just because you find it unrealistic or something...it's Tarantino and Tony Scott, live with it. If you enjoy it anything like as much as I do, you'll love it.
